update.description:
Fixes a segfault on start-up if the wrong qwt was selected.

I updated my local checkout yesterday and compiled Gazebo 8 prior to release to get a preview, but gzclient promptly segfaulted.  This was hard to debug as the segfault occurred before `main()`.  After a lot of head-scratching and recompiling in debug mode, I finally realized it was linking to both Qt4 and Qt5 on my Xenial machine.

It turned out the reason it did so was because it automatically selected `libqwt.so.6.1.2`, since I had failed to notice the need for installing package `libqwt-qt5-dev`.  Installing this and re-running cmake (with cleared cache !) fixed the problem.  However, if Gazebo is switching unconditionally to Qt5 for this release, I'd recommend changing `SearchForStuff.cmake` to only use qwt-qt5.

Perhaps this is only Ubuntu-related, and the name `qwt` is used on other platforms.  In that case it would be nice to detect somehow if the selected library is Qt4 or Qt5, because the condition where the program simply crashes before `main()` is very hard to understand.  It occurs for any program that links both libQt5Gui.so and libQtGui.so, which happens in gzclient if libqwt is selected instead of libqwt-qt5.
update.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

pull_request.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

pullrequest.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

content.raw:
Sure checking `Linux` seems like a better option as I think Windows probably also uses `qwt` and not `qwt-qt5`. Would you mind updating the pull request with those changes? 

Thanks for fixing this!
content.html:
Sure checking Linux seems like a better option as I think Windows probably also uses qwt and not qwt-qt5. Would you mind updating the pull request with those changes?

Thanks for fixing this!

pull_request.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

pullrequest.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

content.raw: Ah, thought something like that might be true. Too bad.  Well, to be fair, it does work on Xenial, it just tripped me up rather badly.  It could be left as-is to be safe.  It's probably more correct to have `if(Linux) set(QWT_LIB_NAME "qwt-qt5")`, but just checking them both is probably safer in the general case.
content.html: Ah, thought something like that might be true. Too bad. Well, to be fair, it does work on Xenial, it just tripped me up rather badly. It could be left as-is to be safe. It's probably more correct to have if(Linux) set(QWT_LIB_NAME "qwt-qt5"), but just checking them both is probably safer in the general case.

pull_request.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

pullrequest.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

content.raw:
unfortunately `qwt` is used in homebrew on OSX. I think we could tweak this patch and add a platform check to set the name of the qwt library accordingly, e.g.

~~~
diff -r 2e71e0091b49 cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
--- a/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Fri Jan 20 23:58:49 2017 +0000
+++ b/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake	Tue Jan 24 15:27:47 2017 -0800
@@ -761,7 +761,12 @@
   PATH_SUFFIXES qwt qwt5
 )
 
-find_library(QWT_LIBRARY NAMES qwt-qt5 qwt PATHS
+SET(QWT_LIB_NAME "qwt-qt5")
+if (APPLE)
+  SET(QWT_LIB_NAME "qwt")
+endif()
+
+find_library(QWT_LIBRARY NAMES ${QWT_LIB_NAME} PATHS
~~~
content.html:
unfortunately qwt is used in homebrew on OSX. I think we could tweak this patch and add a platform check to set the name of the qwt library accordingly, e.g.

diff -r 2e71e0091b49 cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
--- a/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake    Fri Jan 20 23:58:49 2017 +0000
+++ b/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake    Tue Jan 24 15:27:47 2017 -0800
@@ -761,7 +761,12 @@
   PATH_SUFFIXES qwt qwt5
 )

-find_library(QWT_LIBRARY NAMES qwt-qt5 qwt PATHS
+SET(QWT_LIB_NAME "qwt-qt5")
+if (APPLE)
+  SET(QWT_LIB_NAME "qwt")
+endif()
+
+find_library(QWT_LIBRARY NAMES ${QWT_LIB_NAME} PATHS

pull_request.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.

update.description:
Fixes a segfault on start-up if the wrong qwt was selected.

I updated my local checkout yesterday and compiled Gazebo 8 prior to release to get a preview, but gzclient promptly segfaulted.  This was hard to debug as the segfault occurred before `main()`.  After a lot of head-scratching and recompiling in debug mode, I finally realized it was linking to both Qt4 and Qt5 on my Xenial machine.

It turned out the reason it did so was because it automatically selected `libqwt.so.6.1.2`, since I had failed to notice the need for installing package `libqwt-qt5-dev`.  Installing this and re-running cmake (with cleared cache !) fixed the problem.  However, if Gazebo is switching unconditionally to Qt5 for this release, I'd recommend changing `SearchForStuff.cmake` to only use qwt-qt5.

Perhaps this is only Ubuntu-related, and the name `qwt` is used on other platforms.  In that case it would be nice to detect somehow if the selected library is Qt4 or Qt5, because the condition where the program simply crashes before `main()` is very hard to understand.  It occurs for any program that links both libQt5Gui.so and libQtGui.so, which happens in gzclient if libqwt is selected instead of libqwt-qt5.
update.title: Remove plain 'qwt' leaving only 'qwt-qt5', since it links to Qt4 version.
